utterances: ...Fuzzy Zoeller--this is Fuzzy Zoeller Acres.
Unbelievable...
Exactly.
Exactly.
You...
Gina, thank you.
Oh, my goodness.
Oh, my goodness.
I may have to go to Costa Rica then, but...
You can go anywhere you want and you can find anything you want.
There are homebuilders here and developers that are trying to find what you want and will build it for you.
All right, Gina.
Well, thanks very much for talking with us.
Take care, Frank.
Gina Razete is a land developer and builder.
She and her partner created two gay and lesbian retirement communities, one in southwest Florida, the other in North Carolina.
She joined us by the phone from Orlando, Florida.
Yeah, Ken?
Yeah.
Let me jump in.
This is a great call, first of all, and congratulations, Gina.
I hope you guys have great success.
Let me first offer a thought and then comment on this.
My preference--everybody's got their personal philosophies.
My preference is, boy, I wish we had a world in which people of different styles and backgrounds and ways of praying could live together and enjoy that diversity.
Now having said that, there's no question in my mind--I've watched the average ice cream parlor go from three flavors--strawberry, chocolate and vanilla--to about 100.
And, you know, there's a thousand TV channels now.
There's no question that to cater to boomers, you're going to see communities for fitness buffs.
...and even colleges are now trying to build housing for their alumni.
So this boom is just beginning.
Let's take one last call and we can go to--why don't we go to Michael, who's down there in Florida already?
You're in the Florida Keys, Michael.
Where do you retire from there?
Michael, are you there?
The answer is you retire somewhere cheaper.
Oh, this is...
Maybe back to Britain.
Michael, I bet you're living on a boat.
I was living on a boat, Frank.
I see.
I actually moved back on land.
We bought a house in the Florida Keys and I'm standing on my balcony in my shorts.
It's not a pretty sight, but it's very comfortable.
Well, tell us--you have a question for us, Michael?
Well, my thing is I'm actually looking to go with my wife to Austin.
We were looking at New Orleans.
We'd actually found a house in New Orleans we were interested in just a few weeks before Katrina.
And we've had to rethink that just a little bit.
And we decided we're going to take a look at Austin in Texas.

I've never really thought of myself as a Texan, frankly, and I don't know how they're going to put up with me, but I've heard that it's a very interesting town, it's got leftist politics, which is important to us.

And we're probably going to go there and hunt down the gay community and see if we can attach ourselves to the edges of that because as your previous guest was saying, the gay community is always the most interesting and vibrant.
Well, it sounds--I want to thank you for your call, Michael, and I want to put one last question around that to Ken.
And that is the fact that apparently, we in this generation feel that we have more choices and we can really take a look at where we're going to live in ways that I guess our parents didn't.
We can slice it politically, we can take a look at cultural distinctions, and it's not just the weather.
Right.

Just like when we were kids, we gave some thought to where do we want to go to college, and that was quite a radical change from our moms and dads that were sort of tied to their, you know, communities of origin or where there moms and dads had immigrated from.
We not only get to think about where we'd like to live, but we're sort of grown up now.
So we can think about where are the taxes reasonable, where do they have good medical care?
Where can you meet people you'd enjoy being with?
And not only that, but if you make a change, it doesn't have to be permanent.
You can try it out for a while, as your callers have mentioned, and then do it again.

And the good news is that whereas in the past somebody with these sorts of appetites or curiosities would not have been met with much response on the marketplace or many options, today builders, developers, community developers, as you've heard, are waking up to this generation and there will be so many more interesting choices out there for high- and low-income people, your head would spin.
Ken, thanks very much.
My pleasure.

Ken Dychtwald is a gerontologist and CEO of Age Wave, a think tank that studies aging trends, and author of ""The Power Years: A User's Guide to the Rest of Your Life."" He joined us from our New York bureau.
Stay with us, we're going to take a look at the bird flu and find out why researchers and medical experts are so concerned.
We're going to learn more about the complex relationship between Turkey and ISIS.
Joining us to discuss this is Omer Taspinar.
He's a professor of national security strategy at the National War College.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you for having me.
Now, for long time, fighters of all kinds in the neighboring Syrian war were crossing in and out of Turkey, right?
And that included ISIS fighters.
In what ways did they use the country as a base?
Well, geographic proximity itself was a major factor.
Turkey has a very long border with Syria, and a lot of the jihadist fighters who came from the West, especially Europe, basically flew to Istanbul.
And the border with Syria is just one bus stop away.
Turkey also, for a very long time, turned a blind eye to jihadist infiltration to Syria on the grounds that some of these jihadists were just fighting a tyrannical regime, the regime of Bashar Assad.
And to top that, Turkey was very concerned about Kurdish independence in Syria.
There are Kurdish groups in northern Syria, and the Islamists fighting against Bashar Assad were also fighting against the Kurds, who are more secular and nationalist group.
So Turkey had reasons in a way to not worry too much about Islamist infiltration of Turkey and Syria, and it paid the price down the line.
What do you consider the turning point when Turkey was no longer turning this blind eye to the activities of ISIS over its borders?
Mainly when ISIS began to target Turkey itself.
When ISIS targeted the Istanbul international airport last summer and killed 50 people, that caused a lot of damage for Turkish tourism, for Turkish economy.

So Turkey began to realize that these Islamic groups, these radical Islamic groups, were not really in Turkey's interest in terms of fighting the regime in Damascus or the Kurdish groups in northern Syria.
In my opinion, in that sense, the turning point was when ISIL began to attack Turkey.
But as long as ISIL targeted the Kurdish groups, on the other hand, in Turkey, the Turkish government continued to have turned a blind eye to ISIL activities.
Now, there was a time when ISIS wouldn't, like, formally claim credit for terror attacks in Turkey even when officials cited them as responsible.
And then this attack over the weekend is being considered the exception.
Do you see this as a sign that ISIS has become bolder in antagonizing Turkey?
Well, it was very hard.
I have three brothers, and I love them all.
Obviously, I try not to think about it when I'm acting, but I was just thinking that if anybody does anything to my brother, I would kill him.
This is the end for this woman, for Sajida Khairallah.
That's how I felt.
I see this as a sign that ISIL no longer wants to have any kind of good relations with the Turkish government.
In the past, there was a hope that somehow Turkey could be a country that would help the Islamic cause.
And there was a sense that Erdogan was on the right side of the war in Syria, fighting against Bashar Assad.
Whereas today, Turkey is not only engaged in a war against ISIL on the ground in Syria, but Turkey has also allied itself with Russia and Iran and has brokered a ceasefire in Syria.
But there's a sense that Turkey's no longer really determined to fight the regime of Bashar Assad.

And ISIL has become more determined in hitting not just Kurdish targets but these kind of Turkish targets and making it known that it is them hitting Turkey, which is I think a sign that they're growing more confident.
We've been hearing that Turkish officials are promising to fight a terror threat, and they say that they have the power.
They say they have the capacity to take this on.
From what we know, do they?
There is definitely a growing sense of determination in terms of fighting terrorism.

However, in the last few months, the Turkish government, the Turkish state has engaged in a major purge of the security and military establishment, including the intelligence community, mainly because a lot of people from the Gulen movement, which is an Islamic movement seen by the Turkish government as the mastermind of the attempted coup last summer - and when you have such a major crackdown with thousands of people being fired, discharged, this is bound to create a certain vacuum, a certain problem in terms of capacity and personnel.

And in that sense, I think Turkey has the political will to fight terrorism, but it is lacking now in terms of human capital, human intelligence and the capacity to fight terrorism more effectively, especially in terms of connecting the dots in terms of these intelligence problems.
Omer Taspinar is a professor at the National War College and a senior fellow with the Brookings Institution.
Thank you for coming in.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Wisconsin Republican Paul Ryan said he'd become speaker of the House if certain demands were met.
One of them was met last night - or maybe.
Ryan said he'd only run if he got nearly every House Republican to back him.
And that includes a group of about 40 hardliners who helped push the current speaker, John Boehner, to resign.
They're the House Freedom Caucus.
They took a vote last night, which seemed on its face a little complicated.
NPR's Ailsa Chang reports.
It's actually very simple.
The House Freedom Caucus doesn't endorse Ryan.
But it supports him - make sense?
Raul Labrador of Idaho breaks it down.
A supermajority of the Freedom Caucus has agreed to support Paul Ryan.
A supermajority, as in about two-thirds of them, say yes to Ryan.
But here's the catch.
The reality is that we didn't reach the supermajority threshold that we needed for the endorsement.
You see, the Freedom Caucus needed 80 percent of its members on board to officially endorse Ryan.
Two weeks ago, they voted to endorse Daniel Webster of Florida for speaker.
